The devs are apparently 12 year olds, running profanity filters but not doing anything about blatant cheating. The game heavily favors the killer (ie. significantly faster, freight train hitboxes, stupid moves that can knock you down from a mile away) so although survivors have the ability to "wiggle" out of the killer's clutches, with hooks around every corner it's a virtually useless tool. I'd say one out of every ten games played will be one against a bot that is just there to farm blood points, and even then be prepared to get paired up with a survivor who hides in a locker the whole game. I am honestly astounded that I even gave this game 1 hour, with 35 other hours giving the benefit of the doubt.

Just a mess of an unbalanced game, with one of the most painful grinds I've seen, and a community which can get fairly toxic (although that's not everyone, and there's a good side to it). I regret most of my time playing this title, and I only play now when I have friends who want to watch me play killer, or play survivor with me. 

At its best this game can be a fun, challenging fight between a skilled team of survivors and an adept killer. Usually though, it's either you get slammed, or slam the other side. Or encounter cheaters - and not even ones who use cheating to win, just ones that use it to ruin the game. Or you get toxic feedback in the endgame chat. 

Sadly, there are next to no competitors for what Dead by Daylight offers, so if you want an asymmetric horror game, this is the only one with staying power.

I want to recommend this game, I really do. However, as much as I enjoy it, however often I come back, the same problems become more and more prominent. I'm not saying I hate this game, nor that nobody should pick it up, but allow me to be more specific.

Dead by Daylight is a unique genre of game. In it, you play on one of two teams: Either one of four survivors, or a killer. As survivors, you must repair five of seven total generators around the map to power the exit gates, all while evading the killer. If the killer catches you, they will put you on a meat hook. You have three total chances: When you are placed on the hook for the third time, you die. As a killer, your job is to delay the generators' repair while trying to catch, hook, and kill as many survivors as possible. There are some games that use this same formula: Identity V, VHS, and Home Sweet Home: Survive, primarily. 

Out of all of these, only Dead by Daylight has the excessive amount of licensed killers and survivors - sadly, Netflix is now making their own Stranger Things games, and they declined to continue that license, so if you encounter a Steve Harrington, Nancy Wheeler, or Demogorgon, they are no longer available to purchase for players that didn't have it before. 

The game is fun at its base, but it does show the extent to which the gameplay is limited. Every killer has one of a few types of powers. Primarily: Gather information, damage from afar, get close really fast, or become undetected. Some of them, like the Nurse, can ignore obstacles entirely. The gameplay is fun, can be exciting, and can be frustrating. My largest problems with it come not from the game itself but the pattern that the developers have established.

Behaviour has a reputation of ignoring problems and pushing buggy patches. One relevant example is that Dead by Daylight had been out for over four years before implementing colorblindness settings - releasing a statement on them only after receiving backlash from a developer getting annoyed at people asking about colorblind modes. 

Many of their perks are incredibly mediocre to the point where you may not use it, even if it were equipped for multiple games. However, their best perks are used constantly and nigh-oppressive. I fear that the game may continue to stale. Certain maps are sided towards one team or another - indoor maps in particular are hell for many killers. If I could trust Behavior to make changes often and effective, this would be less of a problem - but I cannot truthfully say that.

I don't immediately recommend this game. However, if you are interested, I would recommend watching some of Otzdarva's videos - the sub-20 minute ones, not the 16 hour all perk tier list - and moving from there. The game can be some of the most fun I've had, and I wish for it to continue, but the developers NEED to start making more drastic changes for it to continue to last and improve. I want the game to improve because I enjoy it. I will continue updating my review if anything of note happens as well, but as of December 2021, this is my review.

EDIT: As of May 2022, I have picked the game up again for some casual play, and I am enjoying it. Devs have announced a couple perk reworks and plenty of QoL changes. All of my prior criticisms still stand (except the Netflix thing - BHVR couldn't control that at all). The game is fun tho so like go on ahead
